p: Data from frontline healthcare workers in the early HIV epidemic, SARS, Ebola, and other epidemics demonstrates that working at the frontline of a pandemic/epidemic has significant psychiatric repercussions including burnout, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder [ 12, 18]. The etiology of these disorders is multifactorial and includes fear of infection or death of self or family, sense of lack of control, sense of inability to help patients in situations of limited resources, moral injury in situations of rationing, distrust of institutional responses, and social stigma due to exposure.
